poem:
The Order

In restless pause  
menus flutter,  
a leaf in fall.  

Waiters orbit,  
silent stars  
around a sun  
of indecision.  

Fingers dance  
on possibilities—  
the taste of dawn  
not yet sipped.  

Here, the world  
awaits the bite,  
and speaks  
in hushed anticipation.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Are you a ditherer, sharer or pre-preparer? What your menu ordering style says about you | Polly Hudson It’s common wisdom that you can tell all you need to know about a person from the way they treat waiters. However, another restaurant-based measure of humankind has recently come to light: how much they dither about ordering. The food and culture magazine Vittles reached this conclusion after witnessing Rishi Sunak making a proper meal of it". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Are you a ditherer, sharer or pre-preparer? What your menu ordering style says about you | Polly Hudson It’s common wisdom that you can tell all you need to know about a person from the way they treat waiters. However, another restaurant-based measure of humankind has recently come to light: how much they dither about ordering. The food and culture magazine Vittles reached this conclusion after witnessing Rishi Sunak making a proper meal of it
